item.value:
Social media commerce platform
Storeplacer is a social commerce platform. It allows retailers and other online merchants to make their inventory available through social media platforms. Clients can create storefronts for social media like Facebook and integrate secure checkout options. Storeplacer also provides cloud-based inventory management and analytical tools. Their API exposes the platformâ€™s entire functionality for integration and further development. It is a RESTful API that returns JSON-encoded data.

item.value:
http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-use-quttera-website-malware-scanner-api http://www.quttera.com/restapi
Quttera WIS API enables third-party applications or developers to access Quttera WIS data and/or scan a URL programmatically via simple HTTP requests.
The Quttera WIS API is designed primarily to help anyone who uses it to gather the information about the URL/website/domain safety. It allows both the query to Quttera database of already scanned URLs and a request to Quttera Investigation Engine to run the new scan.

item.value:
The Experience API is a service that allows for statements of experience to be delivered to and stored securely in a Learning Record Store (LRS). These statements of experience are typically learning experiences, but the API can address statements of any kind of experience. The Experience API is dependent on Activity Providers to create and track these learning experiences; this specification provides a data model and associated components on how to accomplish these tasks.
Specifically, the Experience API provides:
The structure and definition of Statement, State, learner, Activity and Objects, which are the means by which experiences are conveyed by a Activity Provider.
Data Transfer methods for the storage and retrieval (but not validation) of these Objects to/from a Learning Record Store. Note that the systems storing or retrieving records need not be Activity Providers. LRSs may communicate with other LRSs, or reporting systems.
Security methods allowing for the trusted exchange of information between the Learning Record Store and trusted sources.
The Experience API is the first of many envisioned technologies that will enable a richer architecture of online learning and training. Authentication services, querying services, visualization services, and personal data services are some examples of additional technologies which the Experience API is designed to support. While the implementation details of these services are not specified here, the Experience API is designed with this larger architectural vision in mind.
item.safe_value:

Specifically, the Experience API provides:
The structure and definition of Statement, State, learner, Activity and Objects, which are the means by which experiences are conveyed by a Activity Provider.
Data Transfer methods for the storage and retrieval (but not validation) of these Objects to/from a Learning Record Store. Note that the systems storing or retrieving records need not be Activity Providers. LRSs may communicate with other LRSs, or reporting systems.
Security methods allowing for the trusted exchange of information between the Learning Record Store and trusted sources.
The Experience API is the first of many envisioned technologies that will enable a richer architecture of online learning and training. Authentication services, querying services, visualization services, and personal data services are some examples of additional technologies which the Experience API is designed to support. While the implementation details of these services are not specified here, the Experience API is designed with this larger architectural vision in mind.

item.value:
ZoomShift is the ideal online employee scheduling software solution for any business that needs to manage and schedule employees. Whether you are scheduling a staff of 15 or 100, ZoomShift is able to make staff scheduling simple. All types of businesses from restaurants and hotels to fire stations and schools are relying on ZoomShift for employee scheduling.
ZoomShift's online employee scheduling software is saving businesses time, money, and hassle by simplifying employee scheduling and management tasks. The time and money you save can be used to focus on growing your business as opposed to managing your employees.
The ZoomShift API allows developers to access and integrate ZoomShift functionality with other applications and programs.

Ubiregi is an application that allows an iPad to be used as a register for monetary transactions. All data is uploaded to web servers where it can be accessed online at any time.
Integrate the Ubiregi with your existing systems using the web API. Retrieving sales data, setting up menus... almost everything can be done through the API.

Funnelback is an enterprise and web search platform that delivers powerful search solutions that are tailored custom tailored to business requirements. Funnelback search services enable the efficient navigation of resources by allow users to leverage information assets from multiple repositories.
The Funnelback REST API allows developers to integrate Funnelback results into their applications.

item.value: Fido Markets is a Middle East based trading platform that provides forex, bullion and commodities trading solutions to institutional and professional investors. The Fido Markets API allows clients to access executable streaming prices. The API can also be used to feed Fido Markets' liquidity into existing systems or GUIs to add our the liquidity pool into existing feeds.
item.safe_value: Fido Markets is a Middle East based trading platform that provides forex, bullion and commodities trading solutions to institutional and professional investors. The Fido Markets API allows clients to access executable streaming prices. The API can also be used to feed Fido Markets' liquidity into existing systems or GUIs to add our the liquidity pool into existing feeds.

item.value:
MEDrefer is a service for facilitating the process of referring patients to other healthcare providers. General Practitioners (GPs) can easily find specialists and Allied Health professionals and let their patients choose the ones that are closest or available soonest. Perform and track referrals online. Specialists can create online profiles that highlight their specialties to increase the number of quality referrals as well as their network of referrers.
Allied Health: Broadcast your availability to more GP's, accept referrals and send your reports online.
Integrating with the MEDrefer API allows developers to issue referrals, accept referrals, check referral statuses, and send reports back to the referrer from their medical applications.
:

item.value:
The Open Supporter Data Interface (OSDI) is the result of efforts to create a common API and data structures for progressive, cause-based campaigns and non-profit organizations. The end goal is to lower the costs of moving data between systems, reduce integration costs, and make it easier for developers to create applications using non-profits' data. The API is designed to handle data regarding people, donations, questions, tags, and events.
:
-endpoint is example -is this a "host yourself" api?

The API is designed to handle data regarding people, donations, questions, tags, and events.

item.value:
Joy please don't publish this. This content is for testing purpose only .
The Global Proteome Machine is an attempt to create knowledge from proteomics data and reuse it to solve biomedical research problems. The Global Proteome Machine Database was built to use GPM data to help validate peptide MS/MS spectra and protein coverage patterns. The Global Proteome Machine Database API provides RESTful access to commonly required information based on data from the GPM Database. Responses are JSON formatted.

item.value: OMNISPORT is the market-leading international sports news agency, providing breaking global sports video, editorial, stills, audio and data. Our local and global sports content packages provide over 33,000 written stories, 11,000 video stories, plus data from over 1,700 leagues & competitions and includes the most extensive available coverage of global football news.
item.safe_value: OMNISPORT is the market-leading international sports news agency, providing breaking global sports video, editorial, stills, audio and data. Our local and global sports content packages provide over 33,000 written stories, 11,000 video stories, plus data from over 1,700 leagues & competitions and includes the most extensive available coverage of global football news.

item.value:
F-List is an online roleplaying community. Members are able to roleplay over forums, private messages, and realtime chat. The F-List API allows users to manage their friends, bookmarks, ignores, and character data as well as perform a site search.
F-list is site open to adults to explore sexually-explicit scenes containing fetishes. Accounts are free to make 'character' pages which have a pre-defined format to make it quick and easy to understand important things about the character. Profiles can have over 400 unique fetishes to add to their four fetish lists, representing how they feel about certain kinks and fetishes, and fetish culture as a whole. Profiles are searchable, and the search is powered by a robust system. Every single kink can be searched for, and even every text field a character inputs about his/her character can be searched.
:

Source and details: http://www.ec.gc.ca/meteo-weather/default.asp?lang=En&n=C0D9B3D8-1
The weather layers are available both via the WMS and KML web services standards.

item.value:
AREL ( Augmented Reality Experience Language ) is a JavaScript binding of the metaio SDK's API in combination with a static XML content definition.
AREL allows scripting of powerful, highly interactive Augmented Reality experiences based on common web technologies such as HTML5, XML and JavaScript. You can use it for creating junaio Channels as well as to work with the metaio SDK.
AREL adds HTML5 overlays and easy GUI creation to each metaio SDK project or junaio Channel, allowing cross platform usage of your created Augmented Reality Experience.
Similar to a regular website, an AR experience based on AREL consist of a static part, AREL XML, which defines all the content and links and a dynamic part, AREL JavaScript, which defines the interactions and behaviors of the single Objects or your entire scene. Of course you are not required to define all content statically in an XML file but can as well load it in JavaScript code whenever you want, just like you could with the metaio SDK from native code.
item.safe_value:
AREL ( Augmented Reality Experience Language ) is a JavaScript binding of the metaio SDK's API in combination with a static XML content definition.
AREL allows scripting of powerful, highly interactive Augmented Reality experiences based on common web technologies such as HTML5, XML and JavaScript. You can use it for creating junaio Channels as well as to work with the metaio SDK.
AREL adds HTML5 overlays and easy GUI creation to each metaio SDK project or junaio Channel, allowing cross platform usage of your created Augmented Reality Experience.
Similar to a regular website, an AR experience based on AREL consist of a static part, AREL XML, which defines all the content and links and a dynamic part, AREL JavaScript, which defines the interactions and behaviors of the single Objects or your entire scene. Of course you are not required to define all content statically in an XML file but can as well load it in JavaScript code whenever you want, just like you could with the metaio SDK from native code.

item.value:
Scoresight.io is a football prediction API that uses crowd predictions, social sentiment, and historical results to predict scores of soccer (football) matches.
The Scoresight.io API allows developers to access and integrate the functionality of Scoresight.io with other applications and to create new applications. Public documentation is not available; interested developers should sign up at http://www.scoresight.io.
item.safe_value:

The Scoresight.io API allows developers to access and integrate the functionality of Scoresight.io with other applications and to create new applications. Public documentation is not available; interested developers should sign up at http://www.scoresight.io.

item.value:
Domain Registration Information Service ***WE ARE HOLDING THIS UNTIL WE GET A URL TO DOCUMENTATION FROM THE PROVIDER***
LOL is a set of web tools aimed at web developers. The WHOIS service allows users to query remote databases for domain registration information. The search allows users to discover when and by whom a domain was registered, contact information, and other information. A search can also reveal the name or network mapped to a numerical IP address. The WHOIS API allows to access this search function remotely.

item.value: CMS2CMS is the automated service for content management system and forum data migration. This online service allows to import content, categories, users, images, internal links, comments etc. from your current CMS or forum platform to a new one quickly, easily and for a reasonable price. With CMS2CMS, you can forget about hours of manual data moving. We will take care of it to let you enjoy the new look of your website in the shortest possible time!
item.safe_value: CMS2CMS is the automated service for content management system and forum data migration. This online service allows to import content, categories, users, images, internal links, comments etc. from your current CMS or forum platform to a new one quickly, easily and for a reasonable price. With CMS2CMS, you can forget about hours of manual data moving. We will take care of it to let you enjoy the new look of your website in the shortest possible time!

item.value:
So what's the point of this site? Although still euphemistically 'in beta', the goal is to create a home page for Web 2.0 developers. Content to include news, reviews, comparisons, and examples. Formal APIs, unofficial APIs, and accidental APIs are all fair game. Anything 'programmatic' that's publicly accessible online from sources including Amazon, Google, eBay, Microsoft, del.icio.us, Feedster, UPS, EVDB, WeatherBug, indeed, Blogger and others. Why? Because going From Web Page to Web Platform is a big deal. It's immature and a bit ill-defined but full of potential. To particpate as developers requires understanding, and to do that means to know what the parts are and how they work. Another way to look at this site is from its genesis: frustration. I wanted to get the 'big picture' view of web apis. So I picked-up what books I could find (like Iverson). Pretty good start. But not enough. Then where? Everywhere. Despite what seems like an infinite number of social/web2.0 blogs, sites and businesses, I still couldn't find the 'go-to' place I wanted. What do I think will be good to include here? Descriptions. Examples. Structured comparisons. Graphs. Relevancy. Debate. With what distinguishing traits?
  • Visual. I'd like the blog to be a bit more graphically rich than average: more diagrams, tables, images, and charts. This will take a bit more time and effort, but hopefully it will keep the signal-to-noise ratio high.
  • Timely. If there's a new, notable API released, it should get listed here ASAP.
  • Relevant. There are already more APIs than you can shake a debugger at. Some will get more space here than others. Just not enough of my bandwidth. But the key is to provide a sense of relevance, priority and impact (something that can get lost when looking at a set of del.icio.us tags on 'api').
  • Collaborative. Ideally something more than the usual comments and trackbacks. How can this be a more collective effort? Not sure on this just yet.
  • Educational. At the moment it appears there's no shortage of examples of people using the existing APIs. But frankly, to find them takes a lot of legwork. While I like the books, I don't always want to hit Google Hacks, then Amazon Hacks, to the next one. Although, if O'Reilly folks are listening, how about a hack-of-hacks meta-book...
  • Experimental. Is there a way to 'walk the walk' and make use of those APIs to make this site more useful?
  • Explorative. These new APIs have not only their expected usages but what can be really interesting is when smart, clever people build things that the API creators never envisioned. Not only can that happen with a single API but there's also taking multiple APIs to build a whole greater than the sum of its parts.
  • Beyond nuts-and-bolts. Hit the all-important non-technical topics like legal issues (API restrictions or copyright gotchas) and ROI (where's the money?). At the end of the day these topics may moot the endless debates over REST v. SOAP.
  • Agenda-free but not opinion-free. Because really, what fun is a blog if there's no spice to it? But personally I do not really care if it's WS-*, REST, or morse-code-over-HTTP. Just ask good questions, be creative, solve problems.
item.safe_value:
So what's the point of this site? Although still euphemistically 'in beta', the goal is to create a home page for Web 2.0 developers. Content to include news, reviews, comparisons, and examples. Formal APIs, unofficial APIs, and accidental APIs are all fair game. Anything 'programmatic' that's publicly accessible online from sources including Amazon, Google, eBay, Microsoft, del.icio.us, Feedster, UPS, EVDB, WeatherBug, indeed, Blogger and others.

Why? Because going From Web Page to Web Platform is a big deal. It's immature and a bit ill-defined but full of potential. To particpate as developers requires understanding, and to do that means to know what the parts are and how they work.

Another way to look at this site is from its genesis: frustration. I wanted to get the 'big picture' view of web apis. So I picked-up what books I could find (like Iverson). Pretty good start. But not enough. Then where? Everywhere. Despite what seems like an infinite number of social/web2.0 blogs, sites and businesses, I still couldn't find the 'go-to' place I wanted.

What do I think will be good to include here? Descriptions. Examples. Structured comparisons. Graphs. Relevancy. Debate. With what distinguishing traits?

  • Visual. I'd like the blog to be a bit more graphically rich than average: more diagrams, tables, images, and charts. This will take a bit more time and effort, but hopefully it will keep the signal-to-noise ratio high.
  • Timely. If there's a new, notable API released, it should get listed here ASAP.
  • Relevant. There are already more APIs than you can shake a debugger at. Some will get more space here than others. Just not enough of my bandwidth. But the key is to provide a sense of relevance, priority and impact (something that can get lost when looking at a set of del.icio.us tags on 'api').
  • Collaborative. Ideally something more than the usual comments and trackbacks. How can this be a more collective effort? Not sure on this just yet.
  • Educational. At the moment it appears there's no shortage of examples of people using the existing APIs. But frankly, to find them takes a lot of legwork. While I like the books, I don't always want to hit Google Hacks, then Amazon Hacks, to the next one. Although, if O'Reilly folks are listening, how about a hack-of-hacks meta-book...
  • Experimental. Is there a way to 'walk the walk' and make use of those APIs to make this site more useful?
  • Explorative. These new APIs have not only their expected usages but what can be really interesting is when smart, clever people build things that the API creators never envisioned. Not only can that happen with a single API but there's also taking multiple APIs to build a whole greater than the sum of its parts.
  • Beyond nuts-and-bolts. Hit the all-important non-technical topics like legal issues (API restrictions or copyright gotchas) and ROI (where's the money?). At the end of the day these topics may moot the endless debates over REST v. SOAP.
  • Agenda-free but not opinion-free. Because really, what fun is a blog if there's no spice to it? But personally I do not really care if it's WS-*, REST, or morse-code-over-HTTP. Just ask good questions, be creative, solve problems.

item.value: Here's the initial set of categories for the blog: General, News, Examples, Links, API of the Week, Security, Legal, and ROI. Frankly, if nothing else, it gives me a framework for outlining ideas. I won't expect to get much posting done initially given most time will be spent on site and database setup.
item.safe_value: Here's the initial set of categories for the blog: General, News, Examples, Links, API of the Week, Security, Legal, and ROI. Frankly, if nothing else, it gives me a framework for outlining ideas. I won't expect to get much posting done initially given most time will be spent on site and database setup.

item.value: NewsGator has just released their NewsGator Online API. Some overview in their press release and details in their API Homepage. At first glance looks mostly SOAP based with a subset exposed as REST. Data formats are OPML and RSS, both with NewsGator extensions. Functional API groups for managing locations, folders, subscriptions, feeds, and posts. Authentication by HTTP basic and Digest, SSL is supported. It has now been added to the API reference.
item.safe_value:
NewsGator has just released their NewsGator Online API. Some overview in their press release and details in their API Homepage.

At first glance looks mostly SOAP based with a subset exposed as REST. Data formats are OPML and RSS, both with NewsGator extensions. Functional API groups for managing locations, folders, subscriptions, feeds, and posts. Authentication by HTTP basic and Digest, SSL is supported.

It has now been added to the API reference.

item.value:
Google Talk is all the buzz today. Using the non-proprietary Jabber/XMPP as the protocol is a nice disruptive Google-style entry into the space. Couple of points: clean interface, currently no advertising or popups, requires GMail account. Useful posts on the topic:
  • The official Google Talk site.
  • There's already a Wikipedia entry on it.
  • DeWitt Clinton's post on Google Talk Over SSH
item.safe_value:
Google Talk is all the buzz today. Using the non-proprietary Jabber/XMPP as the protocol is a nice disruptive Google-style entry into the space.

Couple of points: clean interface, currently no advertising or popups, requires GMail account.

Useful posts on the topic:

  • The official Google Talk site.
  • There's already a Wikipedia entry on it.
  • DeWitt Clinton's post on Google Talk Over SSH

item.value: How many Web 2.0 APIs are there? Even if there was an agreed-upon definition the list would quickly be incomplete. Do you see inaccuracies or things that need clarification here? See ways to make this site better? I can use your help. Please use the Comments form for this entry to let me know what I've missed, what's new, corrections, or improvements. Thanks!
item.safe_value: How many Web 2.0 APIs are there? Even if there was an agreed-upon definition the list would quickly be incomplete. Do you see inaccuracies or things that need clarification here? See ways to make this site better? I can use your help. Please use the Comments form for this entry to let me know what I've missed, what's new, corrections, or improvements. Thanks!

item.value: ProgrammableWeb's database of Web 2.0 APIs starts-off with 54 entries.
item.safe_value: ProgrammableWeb's database of Web 2.0 APIs starts-off with 54 entries.

item.value: I just made the first updates to the API database. Surprisingly to me, there's 54 APIs there already. That didn't take long. How well do they all adhere to a strict Web 2.0 API definition? Depends who you ask. My take is that this list includes some general web services that are not purely "Web 2.0", but for now I think it's better to err on the side of inclusion rather than exclusion. Filtering, rating, prioritizing will happen a bit later.

Filtering, rating, prioritizing will happen a bit later.

item.value: I have seen a fair amount of reference to an API for the Audioscrobbler / last.FM online radio services. But, I can't find it now. Does it still exist? Or is it lost, perhaps temporarily, to the merger? A couple of readers have suggested adding this. Which, I'll be happy do do, just as soon as I can verify its existence...

item.value: So much for staying under the radar while I setup this site. Not sure how it happened but within a weekend this site went from getting its first real content to topping the list on del.icio.us/popular. 400+ bookmarks in less than 48 hours. I very much appreciate the feedback folks have already given me including some sites I'd missed (which will be added shortly). Thanks.

item.value:
Thanks to suggestions from readers over the past 24 hours, I've added four more APIs to the list:
  • Syndic8: An excellent directory of syndicated news headlines with a rich XML-RPC API (since 2001 no less).
  • smugmug: online photo sharing service with XML-RPC and REST APIs along with dedicated hacks page on their site.
  • voo2do: interesting task management service ala Joel Spolsky's model.
  • Digital Podcast: new podcast search service via REST API.
item.safe_value:
Thanks to suggestions from readers over the past 24 hours, I've added four more APIs to the list:

  • Syndic8: An excellent directory of syndicated news headlines with a rich XML-RPC API (since 2001 no less).
  • smugmug: online photo sharing service with XML-RPC and REST APIs along with dedicated hacks page on their site.
  • voo2do: interesting task management service ala Joel Spolsky's model.
  • Digital Podcast: new podcast search service via REST API.

item.value:
The impact of the unexpectedly large number of visitors here this week, besides nearly hitting my ISP bandwidth limit (which I substantially increased yesterday), is that the API database is growing quickly. Here's today's new entries with more coming shortly:
  • Gigablast: search service.
  • Library of Congress SRW: database search service (although at first glance the present status of this effort is unclear).
  • National Digital Weather Forecast: SOAP-based API from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
  • UrlTrends: a search engine optimization (SEO) and link tracking service.
  • WebJay: music playlist management.
item.safe_value:

item.value: In a somewhat bold move to catch-up with Google in the online mapping space, it was announced on the MapPoint blog today that the MSN Virtual Earth API is now free for commercial use. What are the gotchas? 1) US maps only; 2) You must support the What/Where boxes; 3) No SLA until Jan 06; 4) MapPoint and VE not integrated. For many developers these limitations could be fine. As another incentive to get developers on board, the Virtual Earth team is offering a $1000 prize for the 'coolest app' developed on their platform by Oct 14th.
item.safe_value:
In a somewhat bold move to catch-up with Google in the online mapping space, it was announced on the MapPoint blog today that the MSN Virtual Earth API is now free for commercial use.

What are the gotchas? 1) US maps only; 2) You must support the What/Where boxes; 3) No SLA until Jan 06; 4) MapPoint and VE not integrated. For many developers these limitations could be fine.

As another incentive to get developers on board, the Virtual Earth team is offering a $1000 prize for the 'coolest app' developed on their platform by Oct 14th.

item.value: As noted in my initial post last month, one of the goals of this site is to build a collaborative technical community around Web 2.0 APIs. The latest of these features is now live: the new Share functionality allows you to directly contribute content including APIs, Examples, Mashups and Reference sites. Using it is simple. Get there via the Share menu item above, or one of the Add Content links over on the left nav, or go directly from within each respective section. Contributions can be associated (tagged essentially, mostly under the covers, for now) with one or more appropriate APIs. This will soon be available as an RSS feed and a What's New type-page will give you a way to see the latest entries. In order to make this easy to do there's no login requirement to participate. As an anti-spam precaution all posts will be moderated and should appear on the live site shortly after entry. In the end the site should feel 'integrated' rather than a disparate set of features (blog vs. APIs vs. other). Let me know if you have comments or suggestions on this feature. There is more community functionality in the works.
item.safe_value:
As noted in my initial post last month, one of the goals of this site is to build a collaborative technical community around Web 2.0 APIs. The latest of these features is now live: the new Share functionality allows you to directly contribute content including APIs, Examples, Mashups and Reference sites.

Using it is simple. Get there via the Share menu item above, or one of the Add Content links over on the left nav, or go directly from within each respective section. Contributions can be associated (tagged essentially, mostly under the covers, for now) with one or more appropriate APIs. This will soon be available as an RSS feed and a What's New type-page will give you a way to see the latest entries.

In order to make this easy to do there's no login requirement to participate. As an anti-spam precaution all posts will be moderated and should appear on the live site shortly after entry.

In the end the site should feel 'integrated' rather than a disparate set of features (blog vs. APIs vs. other). Let me know if you have comments or suggestions on this feature. There is more community functionality in the works.

item.value: Web APIs are the new battlefield between Microsoft and Google. As news.com reports there will be a series of Web API announcements from Microsoft this week at their Professional Developers Conference in LA. Dare Obasanjo in his blog says this includes MSN Virtual Earth, MSN Messenger, Start.com, and MSN Search. In yet another prize-for-coolest-app comes the World's Best App contest to showcase the new MSN Messenger Activity API (maybe 'coolest app' will become a required marketing move for vendors looking to generate interest in their new APIs?). Must be Google's turn for an API announcement soon...
item.safe_value:

In yet another prize-for-coolest-app comes the World's Best App contest to showcase the new MSN Messenger Activity API (maybe 'coolest app' will become a required marketing move for vendors looking to generate interest in their new APIs?).

Must be Google's turn for an API announcement soon...

item.value:
Thanks again to suggestions from readers, 8 APIs have been added:
  • The Internet Archive: A non-profit online repository
  • Yahoo Ads: Online ad management
  • Telcontar: Location- based services
  • Data On Call: Fax services
  • Amazon Simple Queue Service: Internet-based queuing
  • Scribble: Link management
  • Trekmail: Messaging services
  • Wordtracker: Search engine optimization (SEO) services

item.value: Latest site feature: integrated Google search. See the familiar box on right nav bar. This searches the the APIs, the blog and the rest of the site. Give it a try.
item.safe_value: Latest site feature: integrated Google search. See the familiar box on right nav bar. This searches the the APIs, the blog and the rest of the site. Give it a try.

item.value:
Latest vendor to enter the code-for-prizes space: Amazon. Today they announced a $5,000 prize for building "an innovative and entrepreneurial application using Visual Studio 2005 with Amazon Web Services". And in case it isn't obvious from that sentence, it's jointly sponsored by Microsoft and is coordinated with this week's Microsoft PDC in LA (despite yesterday's blackout). The contest basics:
  • Winning app will be selected based on creatvity, degree of AWS integration, commercial appeal and fit and polish.
  • Starts today, submissions due by Dec 31st, and winner announced March 31st 2006.
item.safe_value:
Latest vendor to enter the code-for-prizes space: Amazon. Today they announced a $5,000 prize for building "an innovative and entrepreneurial application using Visual Studio 2005 with Amazon Web Services". And in case it isn't obvious from that sentence, it's jointly sponsored by Microsoft and is coordinated with this week's Microsoft PDC in LA (despite yesterday's blackout).

The contest basics:

  • Winning app will be selected based on creatvity, degree of AWS integration, commercial appeal and fit and polish.
  • Starts today, submissions due by Dec 31st, and winner announced March 31st 2006.

item.value: The we-gotta-have-a-cool-app-contest fever has now spread to NewsGator. They have just announced that they are looking for "the most innovative uses" of their API. Developers can win a Dell Latitude D610 or Apple Powerbook G4 laptop (first prize) or iPod nano (second prize). Criteria are similar to Amazon's: usability, presentation, functionality, usefulness, and originality. Started yesterday, submissions due by Nov 11th and winners announced on Dec 5th. Code away. I will summarize the "API cool-app contests" that I'm aware of shortly...

item.value:
Microsoft folks had a busy day at the PDC. Developments include:
  • MSN Developer Center: featuring tools and SDKs for MSN Search, Messenger, Virtual Earth and Start.com.
  • Microsoft Gadgets: a "new category of mini-application designed to provide information, useful look-up, or enhance an application or service on your Windows PC or the Web." Such as a 'weather gadget', 'RSS gadget', or an internal 'business gadget'. More details at the blog.
  • Start.com/developer: is now in 'preview' mode.
  • ASP.NET Atlas: The .NET take on AJAX.
More at cnet.

item.value:
More reader suggestions have come through:
  • Six Apart/TypePad: hosted blogging service
  • LiveJournal: hosted blogging community
  • Skype: famous for their free VoIP phone service, now part of eBay of course
  • Moreover: News delivery services (note this is primarily for commercial OEM use)
Note that these have come through the 'Suggestion Box' or direct email to myself, but I suspect once the Add Your Favorites feature is rolled-out this week, they'll come through that channel ;-)

item.value: Over two dozen examples and mashups were added to the API database yesterday. Some favorites include flickr world map, comeuppance visualization of upcoming.org events, Sideways movie tribute map (Yahoo), Celebrity Maps, and the useful to us in this neighborhood Seattle Bus Monster. For more see the Examples and Mahsups lists.

Over two dozen examples and mashups were added to the API database yesterday. Some favorites include flickr world map, comeuppance visualization of upcoming.org events, Sideways movie tribute map (Yahoo), Celebrity Maps, and the useful to us in this neighborhood Seattle Bus Monster.

For more see the Examples and Mahsups lists.

item.value:
Latest entries include:
  • GraphMagic graph and chart services (commercial with limited trial offer).
  • Orb digital media access services.
  • Prodigem file sharing API for BitTorrent.
  • TypeKey authentication management from Six Apart.
  • StrikeIron web services marketplace.

Latest entries include:

item.value: Chris Law who last week started the wsfinder wiki, blog and very interesting Map of the Web 2.0 World has suggested that it might make sense to join forces, along with the new Web API Tracker blog, "give the community one definitive place to go" for Web API resources. I completely agree. Given the degree of interest (see below for evidence) I think that by working jointly we can do more, and do it more cohesively, than we could on our own. Funny how in just a few weeks there went from being no centralized resources on the topic to at least three. (Speaking of interest in the topic, in just the last two weeks at ProgrammableWeb here's some of what's happened: starting Labor Day weekend traffic skyrocketed (as noted earlier); number of Google links to "ProgrammableWeb" went from less than 10 to about 36,000; there's a few hundred blog subscribers; almost 1,000 del.cio.us bookmarks; and the site got some very nice comments from folks like Chad Dickerson and Richard MacManus as well as an O'Reilly Radar pickup . Surprised the heck out of me.) Now that there's a few of us working on this topic it should be all the better by building a wider community. Chris, I'll buy the next round ;-)
item.safe_value:
Chris Law who last week started the wsfinder wiki, blog and very interesting Map of the Web 2.0 World has suggested that it might make sense to join forces, along with the new Web API Tracker blog, "give the community one definitive place to go" for Web API resources. I completely agree. Given the degree of interest (see below for evidence) I think that by working jointly we can do more, and do it more cohesively, than we could on our own. Funny how in just a few weeks there went from being no centralized resources on the topic to at least three.

(Speaking of interest in the topic, in just the last two weeks at ProgrammableWeb here's some of what's happened: starting Labor Day weekend traffic skyrocketed (as noted earlier); number of Google links to "ProgrammableWeb" went from less than 10 to about 36,000; there's a few hundred blog subscribers; almost 1,000 del.cio.us bookmarks; and the site got some very nice comments from folks like Chad Dickerson and Richard MacManus as well as an O'Reilly Radar pickup . Surprised the heck out of me.)

Now that there's a few of us working on this topic it should be all the better by building a wider community.

Chris, I'll buy the next round ;-)

item.value:
A couple of interesting additions to the API database:
  • HotOrNot, the dating/rating site that had quite a buzz last year, also offers an API. There's also a fun mashup of this with Google Maps.
  • Cdyne provides a variety of data over web services. For example, includes Phone Verifier and Credit Card Verifier functions. Primarily a commercial, fee-based service.

item.value:
A couple of examples / mashups added:
  • Cheap Gas: a clever way to find cheap gas (if that's still possible) via combination of Google Maps and gas price data.
  • smugMaps: overlays smugMug photos onto Google Maps.

A couple of interesting mashups:
  • Placeopedia: allows you to geographically place Wikipedia articles on top of Google maps.
  • Daily Mashup: combines currently popular items from Flickr, Del.icio.us, furl, and Yahoo News.

Two API additions today:
  • Urban Dictionary: an API for when you're curious about what frontin, party foul, low pro po, and tool really mean.
  • AmphetaRate: a news feed aggregation service.

item.value: Near real-time tracking of Hurricane Rita overlaid onto a Google Map. From the Central Florida Hurricane Center.
item.safe_value: Near real-time tracking of Hurricane Rita overlaid onto a Google Map. From the Central Florida Hurricane Center.

item.value: The Web 2.0 Mashup Matrix is now online here at ProgrammableWeb. What is it? It's an experimental interactive grid with Web 2.0 API's along each axis and the intersecting cells correspond to the mashups made by combining each pair of APIs. As you move the cursor across the grid a box dynamically displays details about each intersection. You can go directly from the matrix to view the examples or drill-down into this site's API database. The page is updated daily. You can get more details at the matrix's About page. There are approximately 30 mashups included now but this list should grow quickly over the next few weeks. Readers are welcome to contribute mashups and examples through this simple form. Mashups are a very interesting piece of the Web 2.0 puzzle and in some ways the most interesting piece. I'll post more on them shortly. In the meantime here are links to a couple of recent mainstream press mashup stories: BusinessWeek's "Mix, Match and Mutate" and The Economist's "Mashing the Web". The matrix is certainly the biggest addition to the site since launch. Given that this is a v1 release there is undoubtedly room for improvement and new ideas (some of which are listed on the matrix about page). Hopefully it's both useful and a bit fun. Feedback welcome.
item.safe_value:
The Web 2.0 Mashup Matrix is now online here at ProgrammableWeb.

What is it? It's an experimental interactive grid with Web 2.0 API's along each axis and the intersecting cells correspond to the mashups made by combining each pair of APIs. As you move the cursor across the grid a box dynamically displays details about each intersection. You can go directly from the matrix to view the examples or drill-down into this site's API database. The page is updated daily. You can get more details at the matrix's About page.

There are approximately 30 mashups included now but this list should grow quickly over the next few weeks. Readers are welcome to contribute mashups and examples through this simple form.

Mashups are a very interesting piece of the Web 2.0 puzzle and in some ways the most interesting piece. I'll post more on them shortly. In the meantime here are links to a couple of recent mainstream press mashup stories: BusinessWeek's "Mix, Match and Mutate" and The Economist's "Mashing the Web".

The matrix is certainly the biggest addition to the site since launch. Given that this is a v1 release there is undoubtedly room for improvement and new ideas (some of which are listed on the matrix about page). Hopefully it's both useful and a bit fun. Feedback welcome.

item.value:
Since the Mashup Matrix went up this week there' s been lots of positive feedback, new mashups submitted, and site traffic has gone up again (thanks in part to pickups by O'Reilly Radar, BusinessWeek and activity from del.icio.us). Here's some of the added mashups:
  • Tagzania: Social bookmarking and folksonomies for Google Maps .
  • Where's Tim Hibbard?: Interesting use of Google Maps: you can follow Tim as he always carries a GPS-enabled mobile phone and data gets plotted on a Google Map (also uses Cloudberry and his own EnGraph).
  • LinkPut: LinkPut is an experiment that attempts to create a better search experience combining Yahoo search with a wiki type community collaboration to better define the information describing the results returned.
More updates coming shortly.
item.safe_value:
Since the Mashup Matrix went up this week there' s been lots of positive feedback, new mashups submitted, and site traffic has gone up again (thanks in part to pickups by O'Reilly Radar, BusinessWeek and activity from del.icio.us).

Here's some of the added mashups:

  • Tagzania: Social bookmarking and folksonomies for Google Maps .
  • Where's Tim Hibbard?: Interesting use of Google Maps: you can follow Tim as he always carries a GPS-enabled mobile phone and data gets plotted on a Google Map (also uses Cloudberry and his own EnGraph).
  • LinkPut: LinkPut is an experiment that attempts to create a better search experience combining Yahoo search with a wiki type community collaboration to better define the information describing the results returned.

More updates coming shortly.

item.value:
A interesting set of mashups built on Microsoft MapPoint and MSN Virtual Earth (many available at the Virtual Earth Gallery):
  • NASA Space Station Map: See the current location of the NASA Space Station overlaid onto a MSN Virtual Earth (VE) map.
  • geotagr: Use MSN Virtual Earth to geotag your Flickr photos or browse tagged photos on VE maps.
  • Blog Explorer: Find and browse blogs by location with MapPoint maps and FeedMap.
  • News Events Mapped: Mashup of news events (via MSNBC) mapped onto Virtual Earth maps
  • PhotoMap: Nikhil Kothari's photos of San Diego area mapped by location on Virtual Earth. Nice DHTML effects.
  • America 24/7: Virtual Earth used to plot photos from the America 24/7 project.
item.safe_value:
A interesting set of mashups built on Microsoft MapPoint and MSN Virtual Earth (many available at the Virtual Earth Gallery):

  • NASA Space Station Map: See the current location of the NASA Space Station overlaid onto a MSN Virtual Earth (VE) map.
  • geotagr: Use MSN Virtual Earth to geotag your Flickr photos or browse tagged photos on VE maps.
  • Blog Explorer: Find and browse blogs by location with MapPoint maps and FeedMap.
  • News Events Mapped: Mashup of news events (via MSNBC) mapped onto Virtual Earth maps
  • PhotoMap: Nikhil Kothari's photos of San Diego area mapped by location on Virtual Earth. Nice DHTML effects.
  • America 24/7: Virtual Earth used to plot photos from the America 24/7 project.

item.value:
OK, on mashups, but not on the *same* mashup (yet).
  • Supreme Court Zeitgeist: Track current news and opinion about the supreme court with Todd Levy's rich mashup of Amazon, Google News , del.icio.us, Backpack, FeedBurner, and Technorati.
  • UFO Maps VE: When you're bored with court news you then track the latest UFO sightings with this combination of MSN Virtual Earth Maps and data from the National UFO Reporting Center. There's also a Google Maps version.
item.safe_value:
OK, on mashups, but not on the *same* mashup (yet).

  • Supreme Court Zeitgeist: Track current news and opinion about the supreme court with Todd Levy's rich mashup of Amazon, Google News , del.icio.us, Backpack, FeedBurner, and Technorati.
  • UFO Maps VE: When you're bored with court news you then track the latest UFO sightings with this combination of MSN Virtual Earth Maps and data from the National UFO Reporting Center. There's also a Google Maps version.

item.value:
A couple of UK-centric mashups added, both built on the BBC Backstage project and Google Maps UK:
  • Sport Map: Lets you find premiership soccer news by team location.
  • UK Traveldata: maps travel adisories across the country.
item.safe_value:
A couple of UK-centric mashups added, both built on the BBC Backstage project and Google Maps UK:

  • Sport Map: Lets you find premiership soccer news by team location.
  • UK Traveldata: maps travel adisories across the country.

item.value:
Variety of new mashups added which brings the site's listing up to 40. And these latest tend to reinforce the view that mapping is currently the most common form of "mashing-up".
  • Trulia: Allows you to see real estate listings plotted on Google Maps.
  • Pixagogo: Uses Google Maps to geographically place pictures from the Pixagogo online photo service.
  • ZCTA Zip Code Maps: Interactively see zip code regions plotted onto a Google Map.
  • gFeedmap: Combines Google Maps and FeedMap to display the location of websites/blogs on a Google map (via BlogMaps - badge-sized maps for websites).
item.safe_value:
Variety of new mashups added which brings the site's listing up to 40. And these latest tend to reinforce the view that mapping is currently the most common form of "mashing-up".

  • Trulia: Allows you to see real estate listings plotted on Google Maps.
  • Pixagogo: Uses Google Maps to geographically place pictures from the Pixagogo online photo service.
  • ZCTA Zip Code Maps: Interactively see zip code regions plotted onto a Google Map.
  • gFeedmap: Combines Google Maps and FeedMap to display the location of websites/blogs on a Google map (via BlogMaps - badge-sized maps for websites).

item.value:
Reader contributions with an international flair today:
  • Panoramio: Very nice photo + Google Maps mashup. Upload to their site via map UI and see photo+satellite image location together.
  • Vivirama: Allows you to geographically explore LoQUo Barcelona properties listings by overlaying them onto Google Maps.
  • Nanaimo Canada Heritage Walk: Tours the town with photos plotted on a Google Map.
And thanks to readers for sharing (see individual Link Details from the Mashups list for contributors).
item.safe_value:
Reader contributions with an international flair today:

  • Panoramio: Very nice photo + Google Maps mashup. Upload to their site via map UI and see photo+satellite image location together.
  • Vivirama: Allows you to geographically explore LoQUo Barcelona properties listings by overlaying them onto Google Maps.
  • Nanaimo Canada Heritage Walk: Tours the town with photos plotted on a Google Map.

And thanks to readers for sharing (see individual Link Details from the Mashups list for contributors).

item.value:
Latest entries:
  • Xbox Radar: Todd Levy gives us good way to see what's news on the Xbox via a big mashup of Amazon, Backpack, del.icio.us, FeedBurner, Technorati, and Google AdWords.
  • TicTap: An Amazon AWS site with SMS feature, library lookups, bios, images, clips, sales rank tracking, reviews and more. Allows price comparison by SMS too.
item.safe_value:
Latest entries:

  • Xbox Radar: Todd Levy gives us good way to see what's news on the Xbox via a big mashup of Amazon, Backpack, del.icio.us, FeedBurner, Technorati, and Google AdWords.
  • TicTap: An Amazon AWS site with SMS feature, library lookups, bios, images, clips, sales rank tracking, reviews and more. Allows price comparison by SMS too.

item.value:
Mashup of the day:
  • Photofeed: What is it? From the site: "The short answer: A photofeed is to images what a podcast is to MP3 files. The long answer: A photofeed is an RSS 2.0 feed with image enclosures." Can work with photos from mulitple services such as Flickr and Smugmug.
item.safe_value:
Mashup of the day:

  • Photofeed: What is it? From the site: "The short answer: A photofeed is to images what a podcast is to MP3 files. The long answer: A photofeed is an RSS 2.0 feed with image enclosures." Can work with photos from mulitple services such as Flickr and Smugmug.

item.value:
Latest contributed mashups:
  • Streampad: Streampad allows you to stream music from your home machine to any internet connected machine. Uses Google maps to display where people are listening and Amazon to display album covers.
  • gTraffic.info: Google Maps diplaying UK Traffic, transport, roadworks, London and Welsh Traffic Cams. (Slow site from US).
item.safe_value:
Latest contributed mashups:

  • Streampad: Streampad allows you to stream music from your home machine to any internet connected machine. Uses Google maps to display where people are listening and Amazon to display album covers.
  • gTraffic.info: Google Maps diplaying UK Traffic, transport, roadworks, London and Welsh Traffic Cams. (Slow site from US).

item.value:
Although most posts lately have been just keeping-up with new mashups, there are new additions to the API database also:
  • Zvents: New start-up from a great team. Generating a lot of buzz at the Web 2.0 Conference this week. It's an events 'ecosystem' with search, event creation, sharing and calendaring features. Given that Yahoo just acquired Upcoming this week, it looks like a great time to be a networked events service.
  • Tagalag: Lets you 'tag' email accounts (what can't be tagged these days?). Also serves as a mashup showing tagged users plotted on Google Maps
item.safe_value:
Although most posts lately have been just keeping-up with new mashups, there are new additions to the API database also:

  • Zvents: New start-up from a great team. Generating a lot of buzz at the Web 2.0 Conference this week. It's an events 'ecosystem' with search, event creation, sharing and calendaring features. Given that Yahoo just acquired Upcoming this week, it looks like a great time to be a networked events service.
  • Tagalag: Lets you 'tag' email accounts (what can't be tagged these days?). Also serves as a mashup showing tagged users plotted on Google Maps

item.value: The winner of the most APIs Mashed Award (so far) goes to Elicit, a Desktop Blog Client that integrates many RSS and Web Services for creating blog content: Blogger, Amazon, del.icio.us, Bloglines, Flickr, Google Search, LiveJournal, TypePad, Technorati, Yahoo Search.
item.safe_value: The winner of the most APIs Mashed Award (so far) goes to Elicit, a Desktop Blog Client that integrates many RSS and Web Services for creating blog content: Blogger, Amazon, del.icio.us, Bloglines, Flickr, Google Search, LiveJournal, TypePad, Technorati, Yahoo Search.

item.value:
eBay mashup activity:
  • eBay/Google Maps mashup: Shows you where those eBay items are coming from (via Markovic.com).
  • Aytozon: Lets you do Amazon and eBay product search and price comparisons.
item.safe_value:
eBay mashup activity:

  • eBay/Google Maps mashup: Shows you where those eBay items are coming from (via Markovic.com).
  • Aytozon: Lets you do Amazon and eBay product search and price comparisons.

item.value:
In case you didn't make it to the sold-out the Web 2.0 Conference this week, here's some of the best blogging coverage:
  • Richard MacManus: Web 2.0 Conference Post Round-up
  • TechCrunch: The Companies of Web 2.0, Part 1, Part 2
  • Chris Law: Extensive 'live' conference posts
  • Dare Obasanjo: Conference Trip Report series
  • And others: Joshua Porter, Greg Yardley, and Dion Hinchcliffe.
Nice to see a little skepticism mixed in there as well. More on this later...
item.safe_value:

  • Chris Law: Extensive 'live' conference posts

Nice to see a little skepticism mixed in there as well. More on this later...
